subject: RE: [junit] mechanism to maintain session information across testcases?
msgSnippet: From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of James Abley ... I m not sure this is a good way to go - you re losing test isolation It
messageBody:
From: junit@yahoogroups.com [mailto:junit@yahoogroups.com] On Behalf Of
James Abley

On 5/2/05, Akhil Srinivasan <akhilss@...> wrote:
> HI,
> I have a situation where junit testcases will act a as a client
> sending messages to the server. Based on the message returned my
> testcase will pass or fail.
> Additionally I have to have multiple testcases that will send messages
> using the same connection. Note that the server maintains a session
> information on the client connection.
> How do i share this session information(connection + related crap)
> across testcases, so that i can execute a sequence of testcases which
> will all use the same connection. One mechanism i thought of was
> extending a testcase that will contain the connection and use it as a
> fixture, all testcases will call that as a fixture but how do i shared
> the connection from the fixture to other testcases which them selves
> need to send messages?
> Thanks
> Akhil Srinivasan
>

I'm not sure this is a good way to go - you're losing test isolation


It seems to me test isolation is not desirable in this case because the
business logic itself relies on dependencies. It only makes sense to test
that the server is receiving a message if the server started in the first
place.

Consider the following business logic:

1) Start server
2) Create connection pool
3) Send message
4) Receiver of message stores values in the DB

In order to test these four steps, it makes sense to accumulate the state of
the previous phases so that you don't have to recreate it from scratch.

As for the cascade effect, JUnit doesn't allow you to differentiate a test
that failed because it really failed or because a previous test on which it
depends didn't complete successfully, which is clearly needed in cases like
this.

For example, imagine that the connection pool creation fails, JUnit will
tell you "1 SUCCESS, 3 FAILURES" while what really happened is "1 SUCCESS, 1
FAILURE, 2 TESTS NOT RUN".

At any rate, you are right, this definitely sounds like acceptance testing,
not unit testing, so JUnit is probably not the right tool...
